column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=The energy efficiency of buildings is the foremost characteristic of a sustainable built environment , and one that can also affect the thermal comfort of users .
#Text=In order to improve buildings in this respect , various analyses can be carried out .

#Text=The importance of the analyses is particularly evident in the introduction of new technologies that need to be evaluated for their general performance and energy efficiency in different integration concepts .
#Text=Such technical assessments can be achieved by performing different kinds of tests and measurements .
#Text=The latter are particularly successful when combined with real-case demonstrations .
#Text=On the other hand , modeling by means of various mathematical tools is also a powerful technique for evaluating the impact of new technologies on thermal comfort and energy use .

#Text=However , the most effective method is certainly to combine the two approaches in a so-called empirical validation , since this enables the calibration of the model and the validation procedure , and consequently enables improvements in technology and design .
#Text=Building analyses are often implemented through dynamic simulation programs that model parts or all of a building .
#Text=However , creating a reliable simulation model equipped with relevant data is essential for the results .

#Text=Additionally , occupants ’ activities and other events can influence the indoor temperature , and thus can have an important influence on the operation of heating and cooling systems and consequently the energy use .

#Text=Actually , one of the most relevant gaps that was identified by researchers was the difference between the real energy performance in a building and the performance predicted at the design stage , which is mainly due to occupant behavior .
#Text=But , what levels of frequency , intensity and duration for such events are crucial for the system , and should they be included in the model ?

#Text=While it is clear that none of these events can be predicted with great accuracy , some of them can be among the causes of the huge discrepancy between the predicted and the real energy use in buildings .

#Text=One of the powerful tools for performing dynamic simulations is TRNSYS , which is a commonly used software for analyzing the energy efficiency and thermal comfort of large models , e. g. , buildings or building elements under unsteady-state conditions .
#Text=The program can also be used for dynamic simulations of buildings equipped with radiant systems .

#Text=In a few older studies involving TRNSYS computer simulations of a typical office floor equipped with a radiant cooling system , it has already been established that occupant behavior can have an important influence on the cooling needs and the thermal comfort .

#Text=Similar conclusions have been made in investigations of the possible influence of occupant behavior on a building ’s performance and the thermal comfort in conventionally heated buildings : compared to the design strategy used in the model , the measured energy demand can be twice as high and the thermal comfort much lower .

#Text=By means of simulations on the model , which was calibrated using measured in-situ data , Tian demonstrated that certain limitations of the measured data can contribute significantly to the observed discrepancies between the measured and simulated results .

#Text=In a case study , research on the German net-zero-energy-building Ascione demonstrated a performance gap between the expected and the measured electrical energy performance , especially for heating , lighting , ventilation , auxiliaries and equipment .
#Text=According to his research , the reasons for that are related to the pattern of use of the buildings and to the occupants ’ behaviors .

#Text=In fact , a much higher energy demand , 2.7 times the expected request , has been found for heating ( including DHW production , which has a very low impact ) , while those for ventilation , lighting and equipment are much lower , about −36 % , −33 % and −14 % .

#Text=According to D’Oca , energy-usage simulations in models of dwellings in which the occupants ’ window opening and heating set-point adjustments are set by probabilistic functions ( inferred from field measurements ) , were up to 61 % higher than when the control system was simulated in a deterministic way using fixed schedules .
